verses.text: The LORD said to Samuel, "How long will you mourn for Saul, seeing I have rejected him from being king over Israel? Fill your horn with oil, and go. I am sending you to Jesse the Bethlehemite, for I have provided Myself a king among his sons."
verses.comment: "Horn with oil" refers to the vessel used for anointing. God's selection of David is referenced here.

verses.text: Samuel said, "How can I go? If Saul hears it, he will kill me." But the LORD said, "Take a heifer with you and say, 'I have come to sacrifice to the LORD.'"
verses.comment: God provides Samuel with a purpose to explain his journey, to avoid Saul’s wrath.

verses.text: "Invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I will show you what you shall do. You shall anoint for Me the one I indicate to you."
verses.comment: God reiterates Samuel’s role in the anointing.

verses.text: Samuel did what the LORD said and went to Bethlehem. The elders of the town trembled at his arrival and asked, "Do you come in peace?"
verses.comment: Samuel’s presence caused fear among the elders, likely due to recent events with Saul.

verses.text: He said, "In peace. I have come to sacrifice to the LORD; consecrate yourselves and come with me to the sacrifice." Then he consecrated Jesse and his sons and invited them to the sacrifice.
verses.comment: Samuel specifically consecrates Jesse and his sons for the event.

verses.text: When they arrived, he saw Eliab and thought, "Surely the LORD's anointed is before Him."
verses.comment: Eliab was the eldest son of Jesse, and Samuel assumed his suitability for kingship.

verses.text: But the LORD said to Samuel, "Do not look at his appearance or his height, because I have rejected him. For the LORD does not see as man sees; man looks at the outward appearance, but the LORD looks at the heart."
verses.comment: Key verse: God selects based on heart, not outward qualities.

verses.text: Then Jesse called Abinadab and made him pass before Samuel. But Samuel said, "The LORD has not chosen this one either."
verses.comment: Abinadab is the second son, also not chosen.

verses.text: Then Jesse made Shammah pass by. But Samuel said, "The LORD has not chosen this one either."
verses.comment: Same process repeated for the third son.

verses.text: Jesse made seven of his sons pass before Samuel. But Samuel said to Jesse, "The LORD has not chosen any of these."
verses.comment: Seven sons are presented in total, but none are chosen.

verses.text: Samuel said to Jesse, "Are all your sons here?" Then Jesse said, "The youngest is still left; he is tending the sheep." Samuel said to Jesse, "Send and bring him, for we will not sit down until he comes here."
verses.comment: David’s absence highlights his unexpected selection.

verses.text: So he sent and brought him. Now he was ruddy, with beautiful eyes and a handsome appearance. And the LORD said, "Arise, anoint him, for this is the one."
verses.comment: "Ruddy" refers to David's reddish complexion. God chooses David despite youth.

verses.text: Then Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed him in the midst of his brothers. And the Spirit of the LORD came upon David from that day forward. So Samuel rose and went to Ramah.
verses.comment: "Spirit of the LORD" coming upon David marks his divine appointment.

verses.text: But the Spirit of the LORD departed from Saul, and a harmful spirit from the LORD tormented him.
verses.comment: "Harmful spirit" (sometimes 'evil') depicts Saul's spiritual decline.

verses.text: Saul's servants said to him, "See now, a harmful spirit from God is tormenting you."
verses.comment: Servants recognize cause of Saul's affliction.

verses.text: "Let our lord now command your servants who are before you to seek out a man who is skilled in playing the lyre. When the harmful spirit from God comes upon you, he will play the lyre, and you will be well."
verses.comment: Music was recognized as helpful for spiritual affliction.

verses.text: So Saul said to his servants, "Provide for me a man who can play well, and bring him to me."
verses.comment: Saul requests a musician for relief.

verses.text: Then one of the servants answered, "Behold, I have seen a son of Jesse the Bethlehemite, who is skillful in playing, a mighty man of valor, a warrior, wise in speech, and handsome; and the LORD is with him."
verses.comment: David's qualities, including God's presence, are listed.

verses.text: Therefore Saul sent messengers to Jesse and said, "Send me your son David, who is with the sheep."
verses.comment: David’s occupation as shepherd is reiterated.

verses.text: Jesse took a donkey loaded with bread, a wineskin, and a young goat, and sent them with his son David to Saul.
verses.comment: Jesse sends gifts with David, customary for approaching nobility.

verses.text: David came to Saul and entered his service, and Saul loved him greatly. David became his armor-bearer.
verses.comment: David is honored with a significant role as armor-bearer.

verses.text: Saul sent word to Jesse, saying, "Let David remain in my service, for he has found favor in my sight."
verses.comment: Saul is pleased with David and requests he stay.

verses.text: And whenever the harmful spirit from God came upon Saul, David would take the lyre and play. Then Saul would be refreshed and well, and the harmful spirit would depart from him.
verses.comment: David’s music brings relief to Saul; direct cause and effect indicated.
